title: Kathmandu Valley's air pollution has gone down.
content: Rains have improved air quality in Kathmandu, lowering it from the most polluted city to the 50th most polluted. The rain has contained wildfires, reducing air pollution. Air Quality Index (AQI) of 0-50 is good, 51-100 is moderate, 101-150 is unhealthy for sensitive groups, 151-200 is unhealthy for everyone, 201-300 is very unhealthy, 301-400 is hazardous, and 401-500 is highly hazardous.
summary: Rainfall in Kathmandu Valley significantly improves air quality, dropping it from the world's most polluted city to the 50th position with an AQI of 56.

title: Government updates Parliament on preparations for the upcoming financial year's policies and programs.
content: The government has shared its upcoming fiscal year policy and program with the parliament. The government's policy and program will be presented on May 14th. The government wants the main opposition party, the Nepali Congress, to cooperate with them. However, the Nepali Congress has raised concerns about cooperative scams and wants a parliamentary investigation.
summary: Minister for Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs Padam Giri discussed the upcoming fiscal year's policy and programme with the Speaker and chief whips of major political parties, despite concerns from the Nepali Congress about a parliamentary probe into cooperative scams.

title: Kamirita Sherpa became the first Nepali woman to summit Mount Everest for the 29th time on May 12, 2022. It was her eleventh successful summit of the season and marks a significant milestone in her career as a mountaineer. Her achievement highlights the growing role of women in high-altitude mountaineering.
content: Kamirita Sherpa, a Nepali mountaineer, has set a new world record by climbing Mount Everest 29 times. He reached the summit today at 7:25 am. Kamirita has been climbing Mount Everest since 1994 and has also climbed other mountains above 8000 meters 43 times. He surpassed Appa Sherpa's previous record of 21 summits on Mount Everest.
summary: Kamirita Sherpa, a Nepali mountaineer, sets a new world record by summiting Mount Everest for the 29th time, surpassing Appa Sherpa's 21 ascents.

title: The Nepali Professionals Summit, held in Berlin, gathered Nepali professionals from diverse fields to connect, share knowledge, and discuss opportunities and challenges for the Nepali community in Germany.
content:
**Nepali Professionals' Summit in Germany**

The Nepali Professionals' Summit in Berlin brought together 70 Nepali professionals in Germany to share their expertise. The summit covered topics like using skills for Nepal's development, gender equality, and tourism after the pandemic. It also discussed climate change, healthcare, and technology.

The summit aimed to connect professionals, foster collaboration, and encourage contributions to Nepal's growth. Nepal is working on initiatives to involve its diaspora community in its socio-economic development.
summary: The Second Nepali Professionals' Summit, held in Berlin, Germany, provided a knowledge exchange platform for Nepalese professionals in the diaspora, discussing themes including harnessing the diaspora's knowledge capital, climate change, and tourism post-COVID.

title: Rato Machhindranath Jatra, a month-long chariot procession festival, begins in Patan Durbar Square, Kathmandu. The chariot carrying the deity, Rato Machhindranath, is worshipped and pulled through the streets by devotees, symbolizing the arrival of the monsoon season and blessings for good harvest.
content:
Today is the start of the Rato Machhindra jatra.

The chariot of Rato Machindranath, the god of rain and good times, is being pulled from Pulchowk to Gahbahal.

The chariot was built at Pulchowk, and the statue of Machindranath was installed on it.

The chariot will pass through all the toles of Patan, and then go to Jawalakhel, where the bhoto jatra will take place.
summary: Rato Machindranath chariot procession commences, symbolizing the beginning of the festival dedicated to the deity of rain and good fortune.

title: Rato Machhindranath Jatra begins, celebrated in Kathmandu for a month, bringing rain and blessing from god of rain
content: Rato Machhindra jatra started today, where the chariot of Rato Machindranath, the rain god, was pulled with music from Pulchowk to Gahbahal. After it passes through all the areas of Patan, it will reach Jawalakhel for the famous bhoto jatra exhibition.
summary: Rato Machhindranath chariot pulled from Pulchowk to Gahbahal, marking the beginning of the Rato Machhindra jatra, a festival dedicated to the rain god.

title: 105 crocodiles released into Rapti River.
content:
105 Gharial crocodiles raised at Chitwan National Park have been released into the Rapti River to help conserve the critically endangered species.

Since 2035 BS, the park's breeding center has released nearly 2,000 crocodiles, including 1,222 into the Rapti River.

However, crocodile numbers are still low due to habitat loss and movement across borders.
summary: Despite conservation efforts, including breeding and releasing 1,957 Gharial crocodiles into Nepali rivers, their numbers remain low due to habitat loss and cross-border movement.

title: Sarlahi section of the East-West Electric Railway project is 90% complete, indicating significant progress in its construction.
content: 90% of construction is complete for the East-West Electric Railway in Sarlahi district. The project has been ongoing for six years, and they are now working on opening the 30-km track. Construction has been delayed in some areas due to a dispute over compensation for trees. Despite the delays, construction has recently picked up pace. However, the construction company has not yet received payment for the work they have completed.
summary: 90% of East-West Electric Railway construction in Sarlahi is complete, with track opening underway despite compensation issues hindering progress in some areas.

title: Rain is likely in Lumbini, Karnali, and Sudurpaschim.
content:
Currently, light to moderate rain with thunderstorms is occurring in some parts of Nepal. This is due to a low-pressure system in India and the impact of strong winds.

This afternoon, expect partly cloudy skies throughout the country. There may be some more rain and thunderstorms in the south and west, and possibly light snowfall in the mountains.

This evening, more rain and thunderstorms are likely in the south and central regions, and a few other areas.

In the mountainous areas with possible snowfall, people should take precautions as it may affect daily life, including transportation, tourism, and agriculture.
summary: Low-pressure system in India brings light to moderate rain, thunder, lightning, and possible snowfall in various provinces of Nepal.

title: Joshi Dhakal has been promoted to Assistant Inspector General (AIG) of the Nepal Police Force by the Cabinet.
content: Government promoted two police officers to higher ranks and honored 42 sportspeople. The government also appointed a Vice Chairman for the Social Welfare Council and a Member for the Language Commission.
summary: Nepal Police Deputy Inspectors General Umesh Raj Joshi and Bhim Prasad Dhakal promoted to Additional Inspectors General; 42 sportspersons awarded for international wins; Nanda Lal Majhi and Suresh Manandhar appointed to Social Welfare Council and Language Commission respectively.

title: Bridge construction on the Narayangadh-Muglin road is in full swing to improve transportation and connectivity in Nepal.
content:
**Summary:**

Four out of 15 bridges on the Narayangadh-Muglin road are still under construction, but 11 are already open. Two more bridges will open by mid-July, while the last one will open by mid-November. The bridges are being built with a loan from the World Bank. The construction has been delayed by a need to cut a wall and pay compensation to affected people. Once complete, the bridges will help reduce landslides during the rainy season.
summary: Construction of bridges on Narayangadh-Muglin road progresses with 11 bridges operational and 4 under construction, targeting completion of all bridges by mid-November.

summary: Partly to generally cloudy weather with light to moderate rain and chances of light snowfall in various provinces and regions, including hilly areas.

content: Political instability has slowed down development in Nepal. Improving infrastructure, especially for small businesses, can create jobs. Investments in roads, electricity, and communication have been made. The government plans to continue investing in infrastructure in the upcoming year. Political unity is needed to achieve development goals. Nepal can progress if politicians prioritize national interests over party interests.
summary: CPN (UML) leaders discuss economic development and infrastructure improvement, emphasizing the role of political stability and entrepreneurship.

content: Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane says he has been prevented from speaking in parliament about allegations against him. title: Minister Joshi urges immediate aid for earthquake survivors in Jajarkot, prioritizing shelter construction.
content:
Minister Bhanubhakta Joshi says people who lost their homes in the November 3 earthquake need help now. He wants them to get money quickly to build temporary shelters before the monsoon rains start.

The Minister said Nepal has had a lot of disasters lately, including the big earthquake in 2015. He said the government needs to do a better job with disaster risk reduction and management.

He praised the National Reconstruction Authority for its work after the 2015 quake and said the National Risk Reduction and Management Authority has been working well in Karnali Province after the recent earthquake.

The Minister said the federal, provincial, and local governments need to work together to provide disaster relief, but they need more money to do it effectively. He said Karnali Province needs over 100,000 new houses.
summary: Minister Joshi emphasized the urgent need for providing relief and compensation to earthquake victims in Jajarkot, highlighting the ongoing challenges of rebuilding after the 2015 quake and mitigating frequent natural disasters.

title: Tragic Fire: Mother and Son Found Dead
content:
A mother and son in Nepal died in a fire while trying to put it out.

The fire started in a forest and spread to a field where the mother was trying to protect hay.

Her son rushed to help her but they were both burned to death.

Police are investigating and more fires are burning in other parts of the district.
summary: A mother and son died in a fire while attempting to extinguish a blaze in Beteni, Siddhicharan Municipality-10, with another fire still raging in the district.

title: Two people died and two others were hurt in a car accident.
content: Two people died in a tractor accident in Dadeldhura. The driver, Dhiraj Thapamgar, and Bishnu BK passed away. Two others, Sudeep BK and Hikmat BK, were injured and are receiving treatment at Dadeldhura hospital.
summary: Two died and two injured in a tractor accident in Dadeldhura, involving a tractor driver from Dhading and a passenger from Rodang.

title: 24 artifacts returned to Nepal from Hawaii
content:
Nepal's Embassy in Washington, DC received 24 artifacts from Ms. Susan Bradford and sent them to Nepal.

The artifacts are mostly from the 17th and 18th centuries, with some from the 13th century.

Ms. Bradford donated the artifacts to Nepal, and the Embassy thanked her for her generosity.

The Embassy has been working to return lost Nepali artifacts to Nepal and has now sent a total of 63 artifacts home within the past year.
summary: The Embassy of Nepal in Washington, DC repatriated 24 artifacts from a private collection in Hawaii to the Department of Archaeology in Nepal.

title:
**Statement on Israel-Iran Conflict by HWPL**

HWPL, a global peace organization, calls for an immediate end to the conflict between Israel and Iran.

They believe that violence only creates more suffering and that dialogue is the only path to a peaceful resolution.

HWPL urges both sides to set aside their differences and work together for peace.
content:
**Iran-Israel Conflict**

Iran and Israel are attacking each other with powerful weapons, including an attack by Israel on Iran's embassy in Syria. This is a war crime. Iran retaliated by attacking Israel.

The conflict worries the world, as it could lead to a larger war. The recent Israel-Hamas war in Gaza killed many civilians.

People around the world want peace and an end to war. HWPL, an organization for peace, urges Iran and Israel to stop fighting and talk about peace.

The international community should help build friendship between Iran and Israel and provide aid to those affected by the war. A global law for peace should be created and followed to prevent future wars.
summary:
The recent violent conflict between Iran and Israel is causing significant concerns in the international community. The two nations that do not share borders are mobilizing high-end weaponry to attack each other and kill human lives.1 April 2024, the Israeli military attacked the Iranian consulate in Syria. A strike against a non-military facility in a third nation, a nation not directly involved in the conflict, infringes international law and constitutes a war crime. Moreover, on 13 April, Iran responded by attacking Israel’s land. Both nations have pointed their guns directly at each other, and there are growing concerns in the international community that the attacks could escalate into another war.
The Israel-Hamas War in Gaza has killed 30,000 since last year, and news outlets reported on dire situations in Gaza, running out of space for proper burial. The war that has persisted in the region over the past century continuously overshadows the prospect of the coexistence of the human race.
It is a clear indication that the greatest victims of war are innocent civilians. How could those lost lives ever be brought back? What could compensate for the outcry of children and the anguish of the youth in devastated dwellings?
HWPL strongly supports the voices of the citizens, the true protagonists of the global village, who oppose war and call for peace. All nations of the global community must uphold the citizens’ demands, thereby ceasing the unjust war and joining to accomplish peace. Organizations worldwide, in alliance with HWPL as peace solidarity, urge Iran and Israel to put a stop to the acts of aggression immediately and to come forward for conversations to usher in peace.
HWPL recommend that the international community take necessary measures to facilitate the formation of amicable relations between the two nations and provide humanitarian aid. It would be reasonable for all countries to support an international legal instrument for peace that embodies the long-yearned path to peace and to comply with its contents so that we leave a legacy of peace for future generations. HWPL will not spare its efforts for peace and cessation of wars.

title: Nepal and Korea plan to hold a high-level meeting to discuss bilateral relations and cooperation. Preparations are underway to ensure a successful meeting, including coordinating schedules and logistics.
content:
**Nepal and South Korea Celebrate 50 Years of Diplomacy**

- High-level officials from South Korea will visit Nepal to mark 50 years of diplomatic relations.
- Events and programs will be held throughout the year to celebrate the anniversary.
- South Korea ranks fourth among countries investing in Nepal.
- A Hyundai assembly plant will open in Nepal soon.
- South Korea plans to invest more in Nepal's hydropower sector.
- Nepal is a top destination for South Korean workers.
- Nepali workers have expanded into service and forestry industries in South Korea.
- Nepalis returning from South Korea are using their experiences to create jobs in Nepal.
summary: Nepal and South Korea celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations by organizing various events, prepping for high-level visits, expanding Korean investment in hydropower, and increasing Nepali worker participation in service and forestry sectors.

title: Japan and Nepal have many similarities, according to Japanese Foreign Minister Kamikawa Yoko.
content:
Japan and Nepal share similarities:

* Mountainous landscapes
* Democratic history
* Experience with earthquakes

Both countries have supported each other in times of need, providing aid after natural disasters.

Japan has been assisting Nepal's development in various sectors, including infrastructure, agriculture, and education.

Nepal plays a significant role in UN peacekeeping operations, particularly with female personnel.

Japan seeks to strengthen cooperation with Nepal on "Women, Peace and Security" initiatives.

As Nepal prepares to graduate from the Least Developed Country category in 2026, Japan aims to further support its development and bilateral relations.
summary: Japan and Nepal, both affected by earthquakes, share common challenges of nation-building in mountainous terrain and a commitment to democracy, which is reflected in their mutual support during crises, humanitarian assistance, and infrastructure development cooperation.

title: Government commits to supporting and protecting investments.
content:
**Government's Plan for Economic Growth**

Prime Minister Prachanda announced that the government will focus on boosting the economy by:

* Encouraging investors with high morale
* Partnering with the private sector to strengthen the economy
* Creating a good environment for investment
* Replacing imports with domestic production
* Providing jobs and contributing to growth

He believes that these measures will lead to a brighter future for Nepal's economy.
summary: Prime Minister Prachanda inaugurated Hyundai's assembly plant, emphasizing economic transformation, private sector collaboration, and job creation through industry-friendly investment policies.

title: EU to provide assistance to Nepal in attracting investments.
content: The European Union (EU) is hosting a "EU-Nepal Trade Forum" to attract European investments to Nepal next week. The forum will focus on addressing Nepal's need for foreign investments to aid in achieving its goal of becoming a developed nation by 2026.
summary: The EU announces an investment forum in Nepal to support economic development and reduce foreign investment deficit.

title: Transparency and good governance are like two sides of the same coin. They go hand in hand. Transparency means being open and honest about what's going on. Good governance means making decisions and using resources in a way that benefits everyone. Together, they create a strong foundation for a successful and just society.
content:
Transparency and good governance go hand in hand. Auditors are like the nation's economic watchdogs, ensuring clear and accurate accounting. Their vigilance helps maintain transparency in economic activities.

A skilled and knowledgeable workforce in chartered accountancy is crucial for transparency and accountability in organizations. Auditors prevent fake bills and revenue evasion, especially in large-scale construction projects.

The new generation of accountants should create awareness about the role of accounting in economic development and adapt to changing economic situations.

The conference will discuss Nepal's economic crisis and solutions, as well as policy reforms and development.

Noted personalities from various fields were honored at the event. Economists, industrialists, and policymakers will participate in discussions on prosperity and economic development.
summary: President Paudel emphasized the importance of transparency and good governance, highlighting the role of auditors as economic watchdogs and skilled professionals in ensuring accountability and preventing financial irregularities.

title: Nepal's upcoming budget will be presented in a new way to make it more transparent and easier to understand.
content:
**Upcoming Budget to Focus on the Poor and Economy**

Prime Minister Prachanda announced a new budget focusing on the economy and helping those in need. He highlighted improvements in the economy since he became leader.

The budget will consider suggestions from all parties to make it more people-friendly. The government is also working on initiatives for good governance, such as addressing loan scams and land disputes.

Despite some criticism, the Prime Minister remains committed to public welfare reforms. The government has strengthened international relations through high-level visits.
summary: PM Dahal pledges revamped budget, focusing on economic equality, soliciting citizen input, and promoting good governance and international relations.

title: The Nepal Swadeshi Summit 2024 issued a 35-point declaration, including measures to promote self-reliance, reduce imports, and strengthen local industries.
content:
The 'Make in Nepal-Swadheshi Summit' ended with a plan to:

* Improve local businesses and increase domestic production.
* Make locally made products the first choice for Nepalis.
* Ensure a steady supply of raw materials and reduce taxes on them.
* Create a special bank for industrial investment.
* Promote the use of Nepali products in government gifts.
* Develop industrial areas and infrastructure.
* Penalize faulty industrialists financially instead of criminally.
* Review trade and investment agreements.
* Build consensus among political parties on economic growth.
summary: The 'Make in Nepal-Swadheshi Summit-2024' concluded with a 35-point declaration promoting domestic production, investment, and the use of indigenous products.

title: Economic progress in Nepal starts in Dailekh, says Minister Bhandari.
content: Minister Bhandari hopes petroleum exploration in Dailekh will bring economic prosperity to Nepal and make Dailekh an economic hub. The final drilling began on Sunday and will determine the amount of petroleum and gas available. If results are positive, further steps will be taken to process the resources.
summary: Inaugurating the final petroleum exploration in Dailekh, Minister Bhandari expressed hope for economic prosperity if the exploration is successful.

title: Nepalese runners won two titles in Malaysia.
content: Nepali runner Mahadev Rijal won the 21 km half marathon in Malaysia today and the 21 km Climbathon yesterday. This is his second consecutive win in Malaysia. He has also won the 8th Tower Runner competition in Malaysia last year. Rijal is from Beni, Myagdi, Nepal and has been working in Malaysia for 5 years.
summary: Nepali runner Mahadev Rijal won the 21 km half marathon in Malaysia with a time of 0:1:14:48 seconds, following his victory in the 21 km Climbathon event the previous day.

title: Nepal defeated West Indies A in the final match of a T20 series.
content:
Nepal lost the first three matches of a T20 series against West Indies 'A' but won the final match by six wickets.

West Indies 'A' batted first and scored 172 runs. Nepal bowled well and took seven wickets.

Nepal chased the target in 18.5 overs, thanks to Anil Shah (58 runs) and Kushal Malla (37 runs not out).
summary: After losing three consecutive matches, Nepal defeated West Indies 'A' by six wickets in the T20 series finale, with Anil Shah's 58 runs and Kushal Malla's 37* leading the chase.

title: President sends well wishes to cricket players.
content: President Paudel wished Nepali cricket players luck in the ICC T20 World Cup. The tournament begins on June 1 and Nepal is in Group D with South Africa, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and the Netherlands. Nepal's first match will be on June 4 against the Netherlands.
summary: President Paudel extends best wishes to Nepali cricket team for ICC T20 World Cup, which begins June 1 with Nepal facing the Netherlands on June 4, competing in Group 'D' with South Africa, Sri Lanka, and Bangladesh.

title: West Indies Team "A" wins the T20 series.
content: West Indies 'A' won the T20 series against Nepal, scoring 209 runs and Nepal scoring 181 runs. The final match between the two teams will be played on Saturday. Andre Fletcher scored the highest 84 runs for West Indies 'A', while Rohit Kumar Paudel scored the highest 82 runs for Nepal.

title: Nepal lost their third T20 match against the West Indies by 76 runs.
content:
Nepal lost to West Indies 'A' in the third T20 match by 76 runs. Nepal tried to chase 228 runs but were only able to score 151. Karan KC and Lokesh Bam were the top scorers for Nepal with 28 runs each.

West Indies batted first and scored 227 runs. Johnson Charles scored 119 runs for West Indies.

In the five-match T20 series, Nepal has won two and lost one so far.
summary: Nepal lost to West Indies 'A' by 76 runs in the third T20 match, despite Johnson Charles' century for West Indies, as Nepal now holds a 2-1 lead in the 5-match series.

title: Dengue cases in Bagmati province have exceeded 11,000.
content:
Dengue fever cases are common in Bagmati Province (Nepal). Over 11,000 confirmed cases in the past 9 months.

Most cases are in Dhading (3,501). Kathmandu has 3,000 cases.
One person died from dengue fever in Makwanpur.

Dengue risk is higher in summer. Protect yourself from mosquito bites.
Health Office is working to destroy mosquito larvae to control dengue.
summary: As of the end of the current fiscal year 2080-81 BS, 11,409 dengue fever cases have been confirmed in Bagmati Province, with the highest incidence in Dhading (3,501) and one fatality in Makwanpur.

title: Nepal believes that everyone has the right to live a decent life, regardless of their age, gender, or abilities.
content:
**Nepal's Approach to Population and Development**

Nepal focuses on protecting the rights of its citizens when dealing with population and development issues. The country is committed to:

* Ensuring everyone has access to health and education
* Promoting gender equality and reproductive rights
* Reducing poverty and inequality

Nepal recognizes that progress has been made since the International Conference on Population and Development in 1994, but challenges remain, including poverty, inequality, and climate change.

The country is committed to strengthening its health and population policies and programs to improve the well-being of its citizens.
summary: Nepal affirms its commitment to a rights-based approach to population and development, emphasizing the importance of implementing the ICPD Programme of Action, while highlighting progress and challenges in achieving Sustainable Development Goals.

title: Japan donates disaster prevention community center
content: Japan gave Indrawati Rural Municipality a new community center for disaster prevention. The center will help the community prepare for and deal with disasters, including building disaster prevention committees, holding activities, broadcasting information, and setting up warehouses. The Japanese ambassador hopes the center will not only improve disaster prevention but also help revitalize the region.
summary: Japan donated a Community Center for Disaster Prevention to Indrawati Rural Municipality, Sindhupalchowk, including disaster prevention committees, public broadcasting, warehouses, and landslide prevention measures, to enhance disaster prevention capabilities.

title: Dr. Sharma, a parliamentarian, donated 2 million rupees to a children's hospital.
content: Dr Sunil Sharma, a member of the House of Representatives, gave two million rupees to Children's Hospital. The hospital is being built by Dr Bhagwan Koirala. The hospital will have 100 beds in Kathmandu and 50 beds in each of the seven provinces. The hospital will provide specialized care for children.
summary: Entrepreneur and MP Sunil Sharma donates two million rupees to the under-construction Kathmandu Institute of Child Health, an initiative by Cardiothoracic Surgeon Dr Bhagwan Koirala.

title: Dr. Sharma, a parliamentarian, donates Rs. 2 million to a children's hospital to support their care.
content: Member of Parliament Dr. Sunil Sharma donated 2 million rupees to the Kathmandu Institute of Child Health (KIOCH) hospital under construction. KIOCH plans to build children's hospitals in all seven provinces of Nepal, with the first 100-bed hospital being built in Kathmandu. They also plan to build 50-bed hospitals in each province after completing the Kathmandu hospital.
summary: MP Dr. Sunil Sharma donates two million rupees to Dr. Bhagwan Koirala's Kathmandu Institute of Child Health (KIOCH) for a children's hospital in Kathmandu and future hospitals in all seven provinces.

title: Children receiving vitamin A capsules and deworming tablets
content:
- To improve children's health, Nepal is giving vitamin A capsules and deworming tablets to children under the age of 5.
- Children aged 6 to 59 months will receive vitamin A capsules.
- Children aged 1 to 5 years will receive deworming tablets.
- Around 3.2 million children will receive vitamin A capsules.
- Around 2.9 million children will receive deworming tablets.
- Health volunteers will administer the capsules and tablets in each ward.
- Over 50,000 health volunteers and 10,000 health workers are supporting this effort.
- The government provides these services free of charge twice a year.
summary: Nepal's Health Department launches a two-day national program to administer Vitamin A capsules and deworming tablets to children under five years of age.

title: Private businesses want the Prime Minister's help in starting regular flights at Geraldton International Airport.

title: Mount Everest's ropes have been secured, making the climbing season officially open.
content:
"Rope fixing" on Mount Everest is now complete, opening the climbing route for the 2024 season.

The rope fixing team, lead by Dendi Sherpa, reached the peak at 8:15 pm yesterday.

30 mountains have been approved for climbing, including Everest, with 956 climbers receiving permission.

The government has collected 67 crore rupees from the climbers.

summary: Seven Summit Treks Company's rope fixing team opened the climbing route to Mount Everest for the 2024 spring season, with 956 climbers granted permission so far.

title: Today marks the final day of Maha Kumbha Mela.
content:
Today is the last day of the Pindeshwar Poorna Mahakumbha Mela, a religious festival that has been held in Chatradham, Nepal for the past month.

Chatradham, known as ancient Haridwar, has hosted Kumbha Melas for centuries. Every six years, an Ardha Kumbha Mela is held, and every twelve years, a Purn Kumbha Mela is held.

In Hindu scriptures, the Saptakoshi river in Barahkshetra and Pindeshwardham are connected to Kumbha Melas in India.
summary: For a month, the twelve-year Pindeshwar Poorna Mahakumbha Mela in Chatradham, Nepal, has attracted visitors from around the world, as it has been held every six years for Ardha Kumbha Mela and every twelve years for Purn Kumbha Mela, with this iteration being the last day.

title: The government has announced an innovation fund to support the growth of the IT sector. The fund will provide financial assistance to companies for research, development, and innovation activities. This will help the sector grow and create new jobs.
content: Prime Minister Prachanda plans to create an innovation fund to support the growth of the information technology sector in Nepal. title: Today is National ICT Day, a day to celebrate the contributions of information and communication technology (ICT) to our lives.
content:
Today is National ICT Day in Nepal. The day is celebrated to promote the development and use of technology in the country.

The government is giving awards to people and organizations that have helped improve the tech world. They believe that technology can help make Nepal more prosperous, like agriculture, tourism, and energy.

The Minister of Communications and Information Technology, Rekha Sharma, said that the government plans to use technology to improve the country's society and economy. She believes that technology can help Nepal develop. The government is working to make it easier for people to use and adopt ICT.
summary: Nepal marks National ICT Day, recognizing the importance of technology for economic advancement and honoring individuals and organizations in the field.

title: Politics should inspire excitement in investors because it can reveal opportunities for economic growth and stability. By understanding how political decisions impact the market, investors can make informed decisions and potentially benefit from favorable developments.

summary: A draft bill released by the Ministry of Communications and Information Technology emphasizes the use of AI, blockchain, and other technologies for IT and cybersecurity management, while establishing regulations for data protection, cybercrime, and website development.

title:

content:

title: Victims and activists believe that reparations cannot replace the need for truth and justice through prosecutions for past conflicts.
content:
**Reparations for Conflict Victims**

- Government preparing a plan for reparations for victims of Nepal's civil war.
- Victims and human rights groups remind that reparations are not a replacement for other justice measures like truth-seeking.
- Reparations include things like money, support, and acknowledgment of harm.
- Government should ensure consistency across all levels of government in providing reparations.
- All victims should be included, including armed fighters and security personnel who faced abuses.
- Social stigma has prevented many victims of sexual violence from seeking help.
- Reparations should consider evolving needs of victims, such as education and jobs.
- Victims should be consulted to ensure their needs are met.
summary: In preparation for the reparation action plan, victims and human rights defenders caution against presenting reparation as a replacement for other transitional justice pillars, including truth-seeking, prosecution, and institutional reforms to prevent future violence.

title: Fake makeup products that are made to look like expensive brands are becoming more common, raising concerns for consumers. These products may be unsafe or contain harmful ingredients.
content:
**Concerns over Cosmetic Safety in Nepal**

Many cosmetic products in Nepal contain hazardous materials like lead, which can cause serious health problems.

**Lead in Cosmetics**

* Lipsticks and kajal (eyeliner) often contain lead, which can harm the nervous system and cause learning disabilities.
* Lead can also cause hormonal changes and menstrual irregularities.

**Counterfeit Products**

* Many counterfeit beauty products are sold in Nepal.
* These products are often made with harsh chemicals and ingredients of poor quality.
* They can cause skin irritation, dryness, and even more serious conditions.

**Regulatory Measures**

* Nepal has no government agency to regulate chemicals in cosmetics.
* This means consumers are not protected from harmful products.

**Tips for Avoiding Harmful Cosmetics**

* Buy cosmetics from authorized retailers.
* Read product packages carefully and check for lead or other hazardous materials.
* Be aware of counterfeit products and look for signs of authenticity, such as holographic stickers and embossed logos.
summary: Deepika Neupane's face swelled and became itchy after applying unsafe eyelash glue, highlighting concerns over the prevalence of lead, cadmium, and mercury in cosmetics sold in Nepal despite the lack of regulation and consumer awareness.

title: Traders in Nepalgunj are delighted as the Nepalgunj Inland Clearance Depot (ICD) becomes operational. This will boost trade and make it easier for businesses to import and export goods, leading to increased revenue and economic growth in the region.

Currently, eight ICPs operate along the Nepal-India border.
summary: Industrialists and traders hail the inauguration of the Nepalgunj Integrated Check Post (ICP), a joint Nepal-India project designed to promote trade, ease processes, and curb illegal activities.

title: When mythology aligns with life experiences, it provides insights into the human condition, helping us navigate challenges, understand our place in the world, and find meaning in life's events.
content:
**Mandala Theatre's 'Bakhaamma': Exploring Destiny, Love, and Cultural Heritage**

'Bakhaamma' tells the story of lovers Saya and Sikhum, whose love echoes a divine love story. The play questions fate and the meaning of existence, while celebrating cultural identity through mythology and art.

**Mystical and Ordinary Intertwine**
The play blurs the lines between the mystical and ordinary, with the deities Sumnina and Paruhang's love inspiring Saya and Sikhum.

**Kirati Mythologies Preserved**
'Bakhaamma' preserves Kirati mythologies, passed down through oral tradition. It explores the belief in animalism and harmony with nature.

**Immersive Storytelling**
The set design, costumes, and animals create an immersive experience. The vibrant community interactions and folk music add to the authenticity.

**Standout Performances**
Alisha Rai shines in her portrayal of both the goddess Sumnina and the innocent Saya. The actor playing the bee also delivers a delightful performance.

**Themes of Love**
The play explores various forms of love, including romantic, maternal, and communal.

**Refined and Evolving**
While the play has some comprehensibility issues, the writer acknowledges the need for further refinement.

**Celebrating Kirati Culture**
'Bakhaamma' showcases the beauty and significance of Kirati culture, preserving its stories and traditions.
summary: Mandala Theatre's "Bakhaamma" merges mythology and community storytelling through a production exploring love, identity, and harmony with nature, evoking the essence of the Kirati Mundum oral tradition.

title:
Politics and education are closely intertwined.

**Political influence on education:**

* Governments set educational policies and curricula.
* Funding allocation affects educational opportunities.
* Political ideologies can shape educational approaches.

**Education's influence on politics:**

* Schools can promote civic knowledge and critical thinking.
* Educated citizens participate more actively in the political process.
* Educational institutions can influence public opinion and policymaking.

**Challenges:**

* Politicizing education can compromise its integrity.
* Funding inequalities can result in unequal educational outcomes.
* Balancing political interests with educational needs is crucial.
content:
**Political Involvement in Nepali Education**

Political involvement in Nepali schools and colleges has been a topic of debate. Proposals have been made to prevent teachers and students from directly engaging in politics.

After the overthrow of the Panchayat government, political parties became involved in education. Student unions were organized along party lines. Political leaders used these unions to spread their ideas.

Teachers also formed political organizations and engaged in activism. They became tools for promoting political parties.

Some argue that student activism is different from teacher involvement. Students have a history of fighting for freedom and academic excellence. Teachers, however, should not become members of political parties.

Political parties should stop using students and teachers for their own political gain. By keeping education free from politics, we can protect the future of Nepal's youth.
summary: Political involvement of educators and students in Nepal has sparked debate, with the education minister proposing to ban teachers from concurrent political activities, reflecting a long history of politicization in educational institutions, especially since the fall of the Panchayat regime.

summary: Iranian President Raisi's visits to Pakistan and Sri Lanka amid geopolitical tensions, with agreements signed to enhance trade and infrastructure while considering Western sanctions and international financial constraints.

title:
**Why Become a Teacher?**

* **Impact:** Shape the lives of young minds, help them grow and succeed.
* **Rewarding:** Witness students' progress and see the difference you make.
* **Job security:** Teaching is a stable career with job openings in many areas.
* **Flexibility:** Some teaching positions offer flexible schedules, allowing for a good work-life balance.
* **Intellectual stimulation:** Continuously learning and staying up-to-date with teaching methods.
* **Community involvement:** Engage with families and the wider community to foster student success.
* **Personal fulfillment:** Make a meaningful contribution to society and inspire others.
content:
**Teaching: A Noble Profession Underappreciated**

The outdated saying "Those who can't do, teach" is wrong. Teaching is an important job that requires knowledge, patience, and courage. It's about passing on knowledge that has helped generations.

**Factors Impacting the Teaching Profession**

In Bangladesh, teaching is not as appealing as high-paying jobs. This is due to low pay and a perceived lower social status. This has led to corruption, unprofessionalism, and toxicity in the field.

**Solutions beyond Salary Increase**

Raising teacher salaries alone may not solve the problems. Other factors, such as the quality of teacher training and the values teachers pass on, also matter.

**University Teachers and Values**

University teachers should play a more active role in guiding the nation and discussing solutions to problems. However, the system often overlooks good teachers in favor of those who do not deserve respect. This can discourage ethical teachers.

**Collective Values and Priorities**

To improve the teaching profession, society needs to decide what values teachers should instill in students. By prioritizing values, we can create a better education system for future generations.
summary: Teaching, a noble profession facing challenges in Bangladesh due to low pay, lack of respect, and poor recruitment practices, despite its crucial role in passing on knowledge and values to future generations.

title: Adoption in Nepal is difficult due to unclear regulations.
content:
**A Journey to Motherhood: A Woman's Hope and the Challenges of Adoption in Nepal**

Anistha Shrestha, 40, lost her firstborn and suffered a miscarriage. Heartbroken, she found hope through adoption.

In 2017, she stumbled upon an abandoned baby boy and raised him as her own. However, the legal process for adoption in Nepal is still difficult.

Potential parents must be married for 10 years or single over 45. Children are always the priority, and they can only be adopted if no relatives are found.

While the 2017 law clarified procedures, there are still no guidelines for matching children with parents. This can lead to risks for both children and potential parents.

Society's stigma around adoption can create barriers for those seeking to adopt. Same-sex couples are currently unable to adopt.

Intercountry adoptions, once popular, have been banned since 2019 due to concerns about trafficking and abuse.

Despite these challenges, Shrestha's story shows how adoption can bring happiness to both children and families. However, Nepal needs to strengthen its regulatory framework to ensure the safety and wellbeing of adopted children.
summary: Anistha Shrestha and her husband adopted an abandoned baby, but Nepal's complex adoption process, legal barriers, and lack of regulations hinder adoptions and create safety risks for children, particularly for queer communities.

title: Escalating Middle East crisis threatens Nepal's economy. Reduced remittance from Nepali workers in the region and higher import costs could hurt Nepal's stability.
content:
**Nepal Faces Economic Risks from Middle East Tensions**

Nepal relies on money sent home by its citizens working abroad, especially in the Middle East.

Iran's recent attack on Israel has raised tensions in the region, which could lead to a conflict that affects the oil supply and global economy.

This could hurt Nepal by:

* Reducing job opportunities in the Middle East for Nepalese workers
* Disrupting supply chains, causing higher prices
* Weakening the value of the Nepalese currency
* Reducing foreign aid and investment

title: Political tension in Nepal's Madhesh region is high after the split of the ruling coalition. The fate of the Madhesh Province government is uncertain, as it depends on the support of other parties.
content:

The Janata Samajbadi Party (JSP) in Nepal has split, which could lead to a crisis in the Madhesh provincial government led by JSP. The Maoist Centre, which supports the government, is considering forming a new one. The UML, the largest party in the province, may also seek to lead the government. The fate of the Madhesh government depends on the decision of the ruling coalition at the national level, which may now not support JSP. If the coalition decides against JSP, they may have to step down. No party has continuously led a provincial government in Nepal for the past seven years, so other parties are eager for a change.
summary: The Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal's split threatens the Madhesh provincial government, with the CPN (Maoist Centre) considering forming a new coalition with the UML as the largest party.

title: Yadav to challenge new party registration in court
content:
**Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal to Challenge Election Commission Decision**

The Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal (JSP-N), led by Upendra Yadav, plans to take legal action against the Election Commission's recognition of a new political party formed by a splinter group. JSP-N believes this registration is illegal and was done without the necessary legal framework.

The splinter group, led by Ashok Rai, claims the need for change due to Yadav's authoritarian leadership. However, Yadav insists he has been inclusive and denies allegations of autocracy.

Yadav maintains that a split in JSP-N is not based on ideological differences and that he still holds the majority in the party. Despite the split, JSP-N has pledged ongoing support for the ruling coalition government.

title: Politicians sometimes change their positions on issues to fit their current needs or audience.
content:
**Gold Smuggling and Cooperative Embezzlement Investigations**

Last year, the UML, then in opposition, demanded a high-level commission to investigate gold smuggling involving senior Congress and Maoist leaders.

Now, the UML, now in power, has rejected the Congress's demand for a parliamentary investigation into Home Minister Lamichhane, who is accused of embezzling cooperative funds.

The UML argues that their previous demand was different because it involved powerful people who could influence police investigations. They believe a judicial commission was necessary for independence.

The Congress claims that the state apparatus is protecting Lamichhane and demands a parliamentary probe to uncover the truth.

Despite the success of the judicial commission in the gold smuggling case, the UML opposes a similar probe for Lamichhane, while the Congress insists on it.

Experts criticize this partisan approach, arguing that both parliamentary and judicial committees should be used impartially to investigate wrongdoing, regardless of political affiliations.
summary: UML's rejection of a parliamentary probe for Deputy Prime Minister Lamichhane, despite their previous demand for a judicial commission in the gold smuggling case, highlights the differing stances taken by political parties based on their position in government or opposition.

title: Nepali Congress may allow Rastriya Swatantra Party leader Rabi Lamichhane to speak in Parliament.
content:

The police report shows millions of rupees were transferred from cooperatives to Lamichhane's name without proper process. Lamichhane denies any wrongdoing.

Nepali Congress claims Lamichhane misused the Nepal Police and Attorney General's Office to appear innocent. They believe the quick support given by officials shows the need for a deeper investigation.

The opposition party is rejecting the ruling parties' idea to form a committee to look into the overall problems of cooperatives instead of solely investigating Lamichhane.

Nepali Congress has also noticed a letter sent by Lamichhane to the Speaker requesting to speak in the House, but the party has not decided whether to allow him.

The opposition party will continue to obstruct the House proceedings until a parliamentary committee is formed to investigate Lamichhane.
summary: Nepali Congress insists on parliamentary probe into Deputy PM Lamichhane's alleged cooperative embezzlement, despite government's resistance.

title: Seven out of eleven wards in Kolkata have started segregating waste. The remaining four will start soon.
content:
**Waste Management in Kathmandu**

Seven wards in Kathmandu have started separating trash into two types: trash that can be broken down naturally (degradable) and trash that can't (non-degradable). This is being done by the city government to reduce the amount of waste in the city.

The waste that can be broken down is being turned into compost, which is used to fertilize plants. Compost is free and can be requested by city residents. The city is also using food waste to produce biogas, which can be used for cooking and electricity.

The city government plans to expand waste segregation to all 32 wards in the city. They will also continue to sell non-degradable waste that can be reused.

title: Government plans to check pregnant women for mental health issues.
content:
**Nepal to Screen Pregnant Women for Mental Health Issues**

To reduce maternal deaths, Nepal is planning to screen pregnant women for mental health problems. These problems have become a major cause of death for mothers.

**Pilot Program**

The program will start at Paropakar Maternity Hospital in Kathmandu. All pregnant women will be screened during their pregnancy and after giving birth.

**Maternal Mortality**

In Nepal, 6% of maternal deaths are due to self-harm (suicide). 151 women die from pregnancy-related problems for every 100,000 live births.

**Causes of Maternal Deaths**

Postpartum hemorrhage (excessive bleeding after birth), pre-eclampsia (high blood pressure during pregnancy), and mental health problems are major causes of maternal deaths.

**Government Efforts**

The Ministry of Health is making it mandatory for women to have regular prenatal and postnatal care. They are also providing free institutional delivery services and travel allowances.

**Goal**

Nepal aims to reduce its maternal mortality rate to 75 per 100,000 births by 2030.
summary: Nepal's Health Ministry plans to screen pregnant women for mental health issues, which have contributed to the rising maternal mortality rate, with a pilot program starting at the Paropakar Maternity and Women's Hospital.

title: Doctors and health workers receive training to screen for non-communicable diseases (NCDs), such as diabetes, heart disease, and cancer. This training helps them identify and prevent NCDs, improving the health of their patients.
content:

* 50 health workers received training to screen for NCDs like high blood pressure, diabetes, cancer, and mental health problems.
* These workers will screen patients at local health facilities.
* NCDs account for 71% of deaths in Nepal, with smoking being a major risk factor.
* The Health Ministry provides free medicines for some NCDs, but many people don't know they have them due to lack of screening.
* Health workers hope early detection will reduce the burden of NCDs.
summary: 50 health workers in Kathmandu district are trained to screen patients for non-communicable diseases such as high blood pressure, heart disease, cancer, diabetes, and mental health problems, to lessen the disease burden in Nepal, where non-communicable diseases account for 71% of deaths.

title: Less than 2% of medicines on the market undergo testing within 9 months.
content: The Department of Drug Administration (DDA) has tested only a small number of medicines in the current fiscal year. Out of 20,000 medicines in the market, the DDA has tested less than 2%. Some samples that were collected for testing over a year ago have not yet been tested. This means that some substandard medicines may be on the market and patients may be taking them without knowing it. The DDA admits that it does not have enough staff or capacity to test all medicines and ensure their quality.
summary: Despite collecting nearly 20,000 drug samples in nine months, the Department of Drug Administration tests less than 2% of registered medicines, leaving patients vulnerable to substandard drugs due to insufficient testing and a lack of quality assurance mechanisms.

title: Toxic air pollutes the environment, causing young children to develop asthma.
content:
**Air Pollution and Children's Health**

Dirty air in Kathmandu is causing more children to get asthma.

Asthma is a breathing problem that makes it hard to breathe. It can be triggered by things like air pollution, allergies, and family history.

Polluted air can also make asthma worse for children who already have it.

Doctors say it's important to seek medical help if a child has shortness of breath, trouble sleeping, or wheezing.

Polluted air is also shortening the lives of Nepali people, especially in areas like Mahottari and Rautahat.
summary: Air pollution in Nepal, particularly in Kathmandu and Saptari, is exacerbating childhood asthma due to forest fires, emissions, and agriculture residue burning, leading to health hazards for children and women and reducing life expectancy by up to 7.5 years.

title: People in seven districts to receive medicine to prevent elephantiasis.
content:
**Elephantiasis Mass Drug Campaign**

Starting Sunday, healthy people over two years old in seven districts (Jhapa, Dhanusha, Mahottari, Sarlahi, Rautahat, Kapilvastu, and Rasuwa) will receive free anti-elephantiasis medicine for two weeks.

This campaign aims to eliminate elephantiasis, a mosquito-borne disease that can cause swelling and disability.

The government has been running this campaign since 2003 and has eliminated the disease in most districts.

This year's campaign is likely the last as the government may not have the funds to continue it.
summary: Nepal has launched a mass drug administration campaign against lymphatic filariasis in seven endemic districts, targeting individuals over two years of age to eliminate the disease by 2030.

**Aditya Mishra, a Nepali Chef in New York**

Aditya Mishra, a Nepali chef, started cooking in New York after studying engineering. He was inspired by famous chefs and shows. He opened "The Sewing Tin" to share Nepali cuisine and culture, blending it with modern styles.

**Restaurant Industry in Nepal**

Mishra observes a lack of storytelling and community focus in modern Nepali restaurants, as well as rising prices. He calls for a resurgence of creativity and authenticity.

Mishra's signature dish combines traditional Nepali chatamari with French confit duck. The dish includes shredded duck, confit garlic aioli, pickled onions, and scallions.
summary: Nepali chef Aditya Mishra, inspired by Michelin-starred restaurants and the transformative power of food, established 'The Sewing Tin' supper club in New York City to share Nepali cuisine and create a sense of community through dining.

content:
**Lucknow: A Smile of History and Architectural Wonders**

Lucknow welcomes you with a smile and invites you to explore its rich heritage. The city is alive with bustling streets and delicious food.

One of Lucknow's most famous landmarks is Bara Imambara, a massive building built in the 18th century. The complex includes:

* **Rumi Darwaza:** An impressive entrance gate
* **Asafi Mosque:** A beautiful mosque with intricate designs
* **Asafi Hall:** A vast hall that defies gravity with its unsupported roof
* **Bhool Bhulaiyaa:** A confusing labyrinth that tests your sense of direction
* **Shahi Baoli:** A stepwell that provides a cool retreat from the summer heat and offers a glimpse into architectural brilliance

Bara Imambara offers a breathtaking experience that showcases the skill and ingenuity of its builders. Its grandeur and timelessness will leave a lasting impression.
summary: Bara Imambara, built in 1784, showcases Lucknow's history with its grand Rumi Darwaza, Asafi Mosque, Asafi Hall's pillarless roof, labyrinthine Bhool Bhulaiyaa, and temperature-controlled Shahi Baoli, offering a glimpse of the city's architectural and cultural legacy.

title: Explore breathtaking landscapes and discover hidden paths on epic treks and trails around the world. From challenging mountain ascents to scenic coastal walks, there's something for every adventurer seeking unforgettable experiences in nature.
content:
**Climbing Mountains: Tips for Beginners**

Climbing mountains can be challenging but rewarding. Here are some tips to help you prepare and enjoy your trek:

**Before the Trek:**

* **Stay positive:** Believe in yourself and focus on reaching your goal.
* **Prepare physically:** Exercise regularly, starting with 20-minute walks and gradually increasing the duration.
* **Pack wisely:** Bring warm but lightweight clothing, including a down jacket, gloves, and sturdy boots.

**During the Trek:**

* **Listen to your body:** Rest if you need to, and don't push yourself too hard.
* **Stay hydrated:** Drink plenty of water.
* **Manage altitude sickness:** If you experience altitude sickness, stop and rest.
* **Communicate:** Talk to your fellow trekkers and guides.

**Challenges for Female Trekkers:**

* **Underestimation:** Female trekkers may face underestimating comments.
* **Period management:** It's important to pack supplies and plan for period cramps.

**Becoming a Trekking Guide:**

* **Enroll in a course:** Learn essential skills such as map reading and safety measures.
* **Build experience:** Practice your guiding skills and lead groups.
* **Network:** Connect with trekking associations and other guides.
summary: Experienced guides Luckme Syangden and Manu Rai provide crucial tips for mountaineering enthusiasts, emphasizing the importance of a positive mindset, proper preparation, and essential gear while highlighting the challenges faced by female trekkers.

title: Israel has told more people in the Rafah area of Gaza to leave their homes.
content: Israel called on Saturday for Palestinians in more areas of Gaza’s southern city of Rafah to evacuate and head to what it calls an expanded humanitarian area in Al-Mawasi, in a further indication that the military is pressing ahead with its plans for a ground attack on Rafah.In a post on social media site X, a military spokesperson also called on residents and displaced people in the Jabalia area of northern Gaza, and 11 other neighbourhoods in the enclave to go immediately to the shelters west of Gaza City.According to the Palestinian news agency WAFA, 24 Palestinians were killed overnight after Israeli jets targeted several areas in central Gaza.Despite heavy US pressure and alarm expressed by residents and humanitarian groups, Israel has said it will proceed with an incursion into Rafah, where more than 1 million displaced people have sought refuge during the seven-month-old war.Israel’s military said that so far, about 300,000 Gazans have moved towards Al-Mawasi.Israel says it cannot win the war without rooting out thousands of fighters of the Islamist Hamas movement it believes are deployed in Rafah.Israeli tanks captured the main road dividing Rafah’s eastern and western sections on Friday, effectively encircling the eastern side in an assault that has caused Washington to hold up delivery of some military aid to its ally.The White House said on Friday it was watching the Israeli operations “with concern,” but they appeared to be localized around the shuttered Rafah crossing and did not reflect a large-scale invasion of the city.The war was triggered by a Hamas-led attack on southern Israel in which some 1,200 people were killed and more than 250 people taken hostage, according to Israeli tallies.Israel's military operation in Gaza, which it says aims to eliminate Hamas, has killed close to 35,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's health ministry. The bombardment has laid waste to the coastal enclave and caused a deep humanitarian crisis.The Biden administration said on Friday Israel’s use of US-supplied weapons may have violated international humanitarian law during its Gaza operation, in its strongest criticism to date of Israel.But the administration stopped short of a definitive assessment, saying that due to the chaos of the war it could not verify specific instances where use of those weapons might have been involved in alleged breaches.
summary: Israel urges evacuations in Rafah, Jabalia, and 11 other Gaza neighborhoods, signaling a ground attack on Rafah despite US pressure and criticism of possible international law violations.

title: Piracy and unauthorized translation of foreign books are rampant in Nepal, hurting authors and publishers.

**Nepal's Book Market: Unauthorized Translations and Piracy**

* Many popular international books have been translated into Nepali without permission from authors or publishers.
* These unauthorized translations are often of poor quality and inaccurate.
* Author Taslima Nasrin's books have been heavily victimized by unauthorized translations.
* Translating books without permission violates copyright laws and is considered immoral.
* The government of Nepal has a Copyright Act but enforcement is weak.
* Unauthorized imports of pirated books have increased in recent years, harming the book publishing industry.
* Piracy has tarnished Nepal's reputation in the global market.
